awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Computational Optics and Photonics for Deep Imaging of Live Tissue
awd_abstract_narration:
Innovation in non-invasive imaging techniques is part of the effort to provide rapid screening, diagnosis as well as to guide treatment in numerous settings that aspire to offer affordable and efficient healthcare.  Most of the existing high-resolution methods are effective primarily on thin and nearly homogeneous transparent samples or over tissue surface.  In most realistic scenarios, it is important to acquire information at depth within tissue.  High-resolution volumetric imaging approaches may require expensive computational tools for data analysis and complex hardware configurations.  Computational optics grounded on signal processing and image reconstruction concepts offers promising alternatives.  This research contributes to advance the related state-of-the-art in translational cyberinfrastructure and biomedical technology.  Results from this research can improve non-invasive imaging systems for research and patient care while supporting the NSF mission to promote the progress of science and advance the national health.  The development of this project involves multidisciplinary efforts from computer science, bioengineering and electrical engineering as well as educational activities with the participation of students from underrepresented groups.   

This project focuses on providing a framework to support advances on optical imaging techniques that can perform at the needed resolution and speed for various scenarios such as healthcare and biomedical research.  The research plan is geared to creating an advanced cyberinfrastructure with simulation and analysis tools to build a computational optical system for deep imaging of live tissues.  The components of the framework include three-dimensional optical imaging models employing nonlinear scattering theory that integrate tissue optical properties to characterize their effect into the imaging resolution performance.  Additionally, it includes the integration of light-tissue-interaction modeling parameters with compressive sensing concepts and machine learning algorithms for advanced data management.  This project targets realistic challenges in biomedical research, including (i) a gap between complex physics of light propagation in tissues and the design of efficient high-resolution imaging systems, (ii) computational optics and photonics for deep imaging of live tissues, and (iii) integration with reliable and state-of-the-art data analytics and visualization environments.  The simulations and computational optics tools focus on confocal imaging of skin tissue, which is widely used in biomedical research, and is potentially adoptable in the clinic to guide diagnosis of skin conditions.  The education plan addresses three major areas: i) research training and experiences for graduate and undergraduate students, i) course development in topics related with computational optics and data analytics, and iii) outreach to K-12 students and professionals to introduce research issues and opportunities in computational imaging and data analytics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this NSF CAREER-funded project was to design computational methodologies to enhance optical systems for imaging heterogeneous objects under high-scattering conditions. The project focused on integrating light scattering modeling, compressive sensing, and data analytics to bridge the gap between complex tissue physics and efficient high-resolution imaging for deep tissue analysis. Additionally, it aimed to promote education and workforce development by engaging students in research and offering courses in computational optics and data analytics.

Major Accomplishments:
A core achievement was the development of a framework that integrates tissue properties with machine learning models. The project successfully combined compressive sensing techniques and AI algorithms with traditional optical systems to create a parameterization for high-resolution deep tissue imaging. This approach reduced the data required for accurate imaging, which is crucial for time-sensitive applications with limited computational resources. The integration improved data processing efficiency for real-time biomedical applications.

A significant outcome was the development of a physics-informed model that combines noninvasive grayscale images with phase information to generate color maps that mimic histological images. This model, trained on sparse data, demonstrated the effective use of deep neural networks to predict histological structures, even with limited data.

The project also introduced an algorithm that integrates oximeter signals with deep neural networks to estimate hemoglobin levels, a key measurement for diagnosing cardiovascular diseases. The use of large language models (LLMs) was explored to combine clinical data with oximeter signals, advancing predictive models for cardiovascular health.

In addition to these core objectives, the project made significant contributions to multispectral imaging for remote sensing. A deep neural network model was developed for multi-source, multi-scale data analysis, and a sparsity data level parametrization was reported. Computational techniques for lightweight optical systems for snapshot multispectral image acquisition were designed, enabling remote sensing in low-altitude environments where system weight and size are critical.

Significant Results and Impact:
The project led to several key advancements in high-resolution imaging. By integrating tissue scattering models with compressive sensing and AI techniques, the project developed efficient methods for high-resolution tissue imaging. Furthermore, the physics-informed models developed in this project show the potential of artificial intelligence to transform traditional imaging techniques. The developed framework facilitates the transition to state-of-the-art deep neural networks and large language models, promising to improve the accuracy and predictive power of biomedical imaging systems, particularly in histology and cardiovascular disease diagnosis.

The educational component of the project successfully engaged students in cutting-edge research, providing valuable experience in computational optics, machine learning, and biomedical applications. This aligns with the NSF CAREER program's goal of integrating research and education to prepare the next generation of scientists and engineers.

Education Activities, Community Engagement, and Dissemination:
The project team participated in seminars to raise awareness about careers in computer science, computational imaging, and big data analytics. It fostered collaborations with research centers and industry partners, while also providing outreach to K-12 students, inspiring the next generation of researchers in computational imaging.

Summary: During the NSF grant, a computational optical imaging lab was established to conduct research and test algorithms for imaging reconstruction and physiological measurements. The project resulted in 15 peer-reviewed publications, over 15 presentations and workshops at conferences focused on computational optics and machine learning, two AI-focused courses, and three co-hosted summer camps. Additionally, several graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students were trained in optical imaging and artificial intelligence. These initiatives continue beyond the grant.
